user_request: A poem about friendship being a gift that lasts a lifetime.

revision_history.draft:
When you crossed the reservoir's edge
the water didn't miss your name,
but it did rearrange.

Every current reorganized itself
along a narrow column of resistance—
how fish found shelter, how light
bent around what you had been.
The lake held its breath in a way
that looked like discipline,

and I watched from the dock
as water learned to be
slightly less certain
about its own surface.

A week later I stood at the marina,
waiting for a slip to open,
and saw it—
the basin re-seamed along your departure line:

fish tracks converging where you sat,
a faint depression in the ice
that wasn't there before,

and I understood: this isn't loss.
This is how a current
remembers someone's shape
by becoming what
comes after.

The ripples weren't looking for you.
They were simply slower
in that one radius, the way
wave training wave
learns nothing permanent,
forgets everything strictly
the way the body does—

a muscle it doesn't need
untracts itself.

I told myself you'd notice if your name
were written in the water like that,
but I was wrong. The lake
has no alphabet.
It only has the discipline of memory
so thin it looks like absence,

and when you return—
which you will, though not today—
the reservoir will welcome
every molecule back to its original sin

of wanting just a little
bit too much.

That's what friendship does to water:
it makes it practice
forgetting so well
it can't help but greet.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The central conceit — that absence leaves a trace in water, not as void but as altered pattern — is genuinely original. The shift from "the lake held its breath" (a cliché) to something like "water learned to be / slightly less certain / about its own surface" earns its place: it's specific enough to feel observed rather than invented.

The marina passage ("I stood at the marina, / waiting for a slip to open") is the strongest structural move. The poem arrives there with accumulated pressure and finds something concrete — tracks in ice where someone sat. That detail does more work than any other line because it's grounded in physical evidence.

"Untracts itself" is a striking coinage, precise and surprising at once.

The closing turn ("That's what friendship does to water: / it makes it practice / forgetting so well") lands on the thesis the brief warned against — but arrives there through enough earned material that the statement still feels like revelation rather than summary. It works as coda.

### What Isn't Working

**Abstraction creep (lines 23–26):**
"and I understood: this isn't loss.
This is how a current
remembers someone's shape
by becoming what
comes after."
The poem loses its physical specificity here and slides into explanation. "Someone's shape" is vague; "becoming what comes after" is pure abstraction. The marina passage already did the work of that paragraph in four lines. Direction: cut or replace with a single image as concrete as fish tracks.

**Cliché resurgence (lines 19–20):**
"the basin re-seamed along your departure line" — "departure line" is vague and slightly archaic, and "re-seamed" recalls fabric or leather rather than water. Direction: find an aquatic verb that doesn't require the seam metaphor.

**Sentimentality (lines 31–32):**
"when you return—
which you will, though not today"
The poem knows it's trying to avoid sentiment but here it leans on a wish-fulfillment ending ("you will, though not today"). The reader is told the beloved will come back; no resistance, no cost. Direction: let the absence persist in the final image or end closer to the water's truth — its inability to hold anyone permanently.

**Redundancy / refrain weakness (refrain throughout):**
The repeated "the lake/the reservoir" shifts slightly but not meaningfully enough across appearances to create genuine variation. Each time it arrives, the pressure resets rather than accumulates. Direction: if keeping a refrain, let each return shift the surrounding language enough that recontextualization matters.

**Line 12 ("I watched from

revision_history.draft:
When you crossed the reservoir's edge
the water didn't miss your name,
but it did rearrange.

Every current reorganized itself
along a narrow column of resistance—
how fish found shelter, how light
bent around what you had been.
The lake held its breath in a way
that looked like discipline,

and I watched from the dock
as water learned to be
slightly less certain
about its own surface.

A week later at the marina,
waiting on ice that thinned where you sat—
a faint depression, not yet a hole,
the kind of absence no one else would press—

I understood: this isn't loss.
The water slows in that one radius,
not remembering but
slowing down, the way
wave trains wave

learn forgetting is its own discipline,

and when you return—
which you will, though not today—
the reservoir will welcome
every molecule back to its original sin

of wanting just a little
bit too much.

That's what friendship does to water:
it makes it practice
forgetting so well
it can't help but greet
the edge where someone was.

final_poem:
When you crossed the reservoir's edge
the water didn't miss your name,
but it did rearrange.

Every current reorganized itself
along a narrow column of resistance—
how fish found shelter, how light
bent around what you had been.
The lake held its breath in a way
that looked like discipline,

and I watched from the dock
as water learned to be
slightly less certain
about its own surface.

A week later at the marina,
waiting on ice that thinned where you sat—
a faint depression, not yet a hole,
the kind of absence no one else would press—

I understood: this isn't loss.
The water slows in that one radius,
not remembering but
slowing down, the way
wave trains wave

learn forgetting is its own discipline,

and when you return—
which you will, though not today—
the reservoir will welcome
every molecule back to its original sin

of wanting just a little
bit too much.

That's what friendship does to water:
it makes it practice
forgetting so well
it can't help but greet
the edge where someone was.
